{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3446199,"name":"Skuke (aka: Payton)","username":"Skuke","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skuke/{size}/10109_2.png","created_at":"2024-11-11T19:06:57.529Z","cooked":"

This is an addendum to Loctite testing (was: 1678 Robot Reveal 2022), which has been closed. One of my goals of testing was to determine how long after Loctite comes in contact with PC does hazing/cracking start to form.

At MTTD this past weekend, our Alpha bot needed a belt tensioner. Found some parts to use and made a quick and dirty pit fix.
The tensioner was assembled and the bolt was inserted thru the hole drilled into the PC. ONLY THEN was “stick” style blue Loctite applied to the last few threads.

Sigh, I decided the bolt was too short and pulled the bolt out of the hole and smeared a tiny bit of Loctite onto the PC as the bolt backed out of the hole. I was a little lazy and didn’t bother to remove the smeared Loctite (despite knowing better -after all, it was only a tiny bit); sigh again.

Here is the result after less than 6 hours:

Loctite on polycarb-11807×2400 281 KB

Don’t be lazy! Do what you know to be right!

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-11-11T19:06:57.529Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":535,"reads":921,"readers_count":920,"score":3169.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":474706,"topic_slug":"perils-of-loctite-on-polycarbonate","display_username":"Skuke (aka: Payton)","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/loctite-testing-was-1678-robot-reveal-2022/414516","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"Loctite testing (was: 1678 Robot Reveal 2022)","clicks":88}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":21}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":32540,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/perils-of-loctite-on-polycarbonate/474706/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":21},{"id":"open_mouth","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":24,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3446975,"name":"Emilio Ruiz","username":"Emi_Ruiz","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/emi_ruiz/{size}/236130_2.png","created_at":"2024-11-13T05:58:58.123Z","cooked":"

Loctite and polycarbonate are definitely not friends, as a team we have learned the hard way that mixing both element results in the worst outcome possible for polycarbonate plates.

Truly find surprising the state of the PC on the photo, since in our expirience Loctite tends to act quickly in a pretty destructive manner, breaking PC right away after it comes in contact.

Image attached is from a plate we had at our 2023 offseason robot which similar to your story came in contact with it on a small amout and completely broke off the PC.

imagen_2024-11-12_233410038614×613 362 KB

As a team one must learn to respect Loctite and use it very carefuly.

A hard lesson we learned this year is that simple green seems to be worse. Whatever you do do not use it as a lubricant to slide silicone sleeving onto a polycarb tube(it was the only type of soap that we had handy).

We use Loctite 425 for any parts that touch or interface with polycarbonate.

For those looking for Loctite 425, this is one of those instances where McMaster seems to have the best price. Amazon: $33. McMaster: $26. Still a little bit of sticker shock for 0.7 oz.

mcmaster.com

McMaster-Carr

McMaster-Carr is the complete source for your plant with over 595,000 products. 98% of products ordered ship from stock and deliver same or next day.

A little dab’ll do ya… in.
We’ve also had loctite seem to move upthread and get in contact with the PC it was near. The stuff is sneaky.

Found this if you want to do some snooping for chemical compatibility.
https://www.calpaclab.com/polycarbonate-chemical-compatibility-chart/

I just want to pass along this nugget of information shared with me previously by 118.

There is a threadlocker that is plastic safe.

Vex Grip Lock Wheel impressions? Technical Discussion
Vibra-Tite is our preferred thread locker for use on plastics. We used this all season on the Grip Lock hubs with no bolts backing out. It does require you to apply it to the bolts 10-30 mins before install but does have a benefit of not having to be re-applied for up to 5 installs.
","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-11-13T14:53:45.789Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":20,"reads":587,"readers_count":586,"score":252.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":474706,"topic_slug":"perils-of-loctite-on-polycarbonate","display_username":"John Fogarty","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/vex-grip-lock-wheel-impressions/465157/10","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"Vex Grip Lock Wheel impressions?","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12688,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/perils-of-loctite-on-polycarbonate/474706/8","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3447092,"name":"Cory Walters","username":"Cory_Walters","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cory_walters/{size}/7329_2.png","created_at":"2024-11-13T15:12:32.033Z","cooked":"

Watch out for Loctite around AM compliant wheels as well.

True Story:
2018 in queue going on to the field our partners were putting on a AM green compliant wheel on to the intake claw. They lathered the bolt up in Loctite, tightened it down. I warned them that is a bad idea as that will eat the wheel up like acid. They said “nah it will be fine”. in about 90 seconds that wheel came off that robot, through the cube portal in the alliance station wall, into my hands. As I hold the wheel I tell them this is why you don’t use Loctite around the wheel. Funny moment of instant learning. Moral of the story don’t use it around wheel hubs.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-11-13T15:12:32.033Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":565,"readers_count":564,"score":128.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":474706,"topic_slug":"perils-of-loctite-on-polycarbonate","display_username":"Cory Walters","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":22243,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/perils-of-loctite-on-polycarbonate/474706/9","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"laughing","type":"emoji","count":6},{"id":"open_mouth","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":8,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3447142,"name":"","username":"SpaceTaco","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/spacetaco/{size}/187908_2.png","created_at":"2024-11-13T16:29:44.393Z","cooked":"

Is it also polycarb-safe? Their site doesn’t list it in the plastic compatibility list.

Vibra-Tite

Vibra-Tite VC-3 Threadmate

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-11-13T16:29:44.393Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":5,"reads":526,"readers_count":525,"score":140.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":474706,"topic_slug":"perils-of-loctite-on-polycarbonate","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.vibra-tite.com/threadlockers/removable-reusable-threadlockers/vibra-tite-vc-3-threadmate/#compatibility","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Vibra-Tite VC-3 Threadmate – Vibra-Tite","clicks":18}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":12688,"username":"JohnFogarty","name":"John Fogarty","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/johnfogarty/{size}/267052_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57795,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/perils-of-loctite-on-polycarbonate/474706/10","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3447144,"name":"John Fogarty","username":"JohnFogarty","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/johnfogarty/{size}/267052_2.png","created_at":"2024-11-13T16:33:14.866Z","cooked":"

VC-6 has PC in the supported materials.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-11-13T16:33:14.866Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":506,"readers_count":505,"score":121.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":474706,"topic_slug":"perils-of-loctite-on-polycarbonate","display_username":"John Fogarty","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":57795,"username":"SpaceTaco","name":"","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/spacetaco/{size}/187908_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12688,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/perils-of-loctite-on-polycarbonate/474706/11","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3447182,"name":"Skuke (aka: Payton)","username":"Skuke","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skuke/{size}/10109_2.png","created_at":"2024-11-13T17:30:22.128Z","cooked":"
Jorme1:

We use Loctite 425 for any parts that touch or interface with polycarbonate.

Please see the link to the original testing at the top of this thread. Loctite 425 was one of the thread lockers tested and per my test, it was NOT safe on polycarbonate.
All the test samples showed crazing. All the test samples showed tearing after being bent. The control samples did not show any crazing or tearing.
Again, my goal was to try and determine when Loctite might adversely affected PC. My first test of 425 was at 24 hours. If you need to thread lock something on PC, and your time table to use is less than 24hrs. It might be ok.

425 does not specifically state that it is PC safe. The only product I could find that says it is safe for use when in contact with PC is Vibra-Tite’s VC-6. However, I didn’t test it because it’s ~$100 for a 1 oz (?) bottle!

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-11-13T17:30:22.128Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":7,"reads":485,"readers_count":484,"score":132.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":474706,"topic_slug":"perils-of-loctite-on-polycarbonate","display_username":"Skuke (aka: Payton)","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":32540,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/perils-of-loctite-on-polycarbonate/474706/12","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3450002,"name":"","username":"Liamthebuildgoon","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/liamthebuildgoon/{size}/238117_2.png","created_at":"2024-11-20T17:29:39.505Z","cooked":"

Ah yes, loctite and polycarbonate, name a better duo. My team’s big mishap with loctite was when we were assembling our final shooter for Crescendo. One of the members was not paying attention and sure enough within a week the plate was useless.

","post_number":14,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-11-20T17:50:09.199Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":6,"reads":402,"readers_count":401,"score":110.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":474706,"topic_slug":"perils-of-loctite-on-polycarbonate","display_username":"Oliver","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":28649,"username":"CEF","name":"CEF","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/35a633/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":58314,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/perils-of-loctite-on-polycarbonate/474706/14","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3450010,"name":"Garrison","username":"Garrison","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/garrison/{size}/7824_2.png","created_at":"2024-11-20T18:03:56.850Z","cooked":"

We plan to invest in some select sizes of these bolts that have a nylon patch applied to them that helps prevent loosening from vibration (might not be as effective as a chemical thread locker but better than nothing). These should be fully safe to use around polycarbonate and have the benefit of not needing any cure time. Also far cheaper than the upfront cost of the Vibra-Tite VC-6 which I’m sure would go missing before we used all of it.

","post_number":15,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-11-20T18:03:56.850Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":399,"readers_count":398,"score":144.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":474706,"topic_slug":"perils-of-loctite-on-polycarbonate","display_username":"Garrison","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.mcmaster.com/products/thread-locking-screws/rounded-head-screws~/alloy-steel-thread-locking-button-head-hex-drive-screws/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"McMaster-Carr","clicks":31}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":23755,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/perils-of-loctite-on-polycarbonate/474706/15","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3450013,"name":"Skye Leake","username":"Skyehawk","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skyehawk/{size}/179363_2.png","created_at":"2024-11-20T18:16:09.025Z","cooked":"

Definitely a few for the special fastners box, they are useful (e.g. need to go through a polycarbonate plate into a blind hole in AL or into a nut strip), although these are effectively single use items before the patch loses its properties, at least to my knowledge, (there are probably a few types that hold up better).

Low profile nylocks are my go to for most applications, but you can not always make this work (and they can be a pain to install in tight spaces when you should just tap the hole instead of a clearence & nut on the other side)

","post_number":16,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-11-20T18:17:23.494Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":15,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":410,"readers_count":409,"score":117.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":474706,"topic_slug":"perils-of-loctite-on-polycarbonate","display_username":"Skye Leake","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":23755,"username":"Garrison","name":"Garrison","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/garrison/{size}/7824_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":19235,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Pretengineer"},"post_url":"/t/perils-of-loctite-on-polycarbonate/474706/16","custom_user_title":"Pretengineer","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3459069,"name":"Frank Lima","username":"franklima260","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/franklima260/{size}/4291_2.png","created_at":"2024-12-13T23:17:35.974Z","cooked":"
REV Robotics 2024 / 2025

MAXComposite Sheets - This is a new material that we believe will become the new building standard for FRC teams. Lighter weight and stiffer than polycarbonate, laser-cuttable, and does not react to Loctite. The general type of this material is called SRPP self-reinforced polypropylene and is widely used in military armor applications as well as things like Battlebots. The issue is that until now, it has not been available in smaller sheets and runs. REV worked directly with the USA manufacturer of this to formulate a specific material that is designed for the demands of the robotics community.

This is an expensive material, and we hope that with increased adoption the price will fall in the future. The workflow that my team 2714, 3005 , 1745, and a few other who used similar materials in 2024, was to laser cut parts out of Plywood underlayment for prototypes and then cut the final parts out of the SRPP. This means you can use the same Laser files as your final prototype with no need to do CAM for a CNC router.

The MAXComposite comes in both .1 in and .2 in thicknesses, and we are really excited to see what teams do with it this year and in years to come.

image960×960 84.3 KB

REV Robotics 2024 / 2025 General Forum

VC-3 also comes as a tape, which doesn’t suck.

(I tend to design for nylocks with 2 threads visible past the plastic & call it a day. I am comfortable enforcing PC-safe design details, don’t need to splash out for SRPP)

I found this cool video a while back that demonstrates the effects of thread locker on polycarbonate. I always show this to students when they ask why we use CA glue or Vibra-Tite’s VC-6 instead of Loctite for fasteners that come into contact with polycarbonate or when we can’t wait for the Loctite to fully cure.

Edit:
This person also made a great video explaining what is going on here in depth.

adhersh:

This person also made a great video…

Thanks for sharing! The testing process in the video was fairly similar to mine. Most notably, I used smaller/shorter pieces of PC (to not waste material) and I bent my pieces of plastic >45° and <90°. -I don’t think many FRC PC parts get bent 180° and even 90° would be a lot.
Regardless, the results were basically the same. Lots of crazing, tearing, and fracturing.
